title: Parents sue Fortnite for being too addictive
text:
Fortnite is to get its day in court

A new class action lawsuit in Canada claims that Epic Games knowingly created Fortnite to be a ‘very, very addictive game’.

Fortnite has been compared to nicotine and tobacco in a new legal filing in Canada, as the parents of two minors, aged 10 and 15, complain that Epic Games specifically designed the game to be addictive.

The law firm is seeking clearance to launch a class action lawsuit, which will allow anyone else in Canada with the same issue to join the complaint.

The suit is based on a 2015 judgement that ruled tobacco companies didn’t warn their customers about the dangers of smoking, which led to a multi-billion-dollar lawsuit.

‘Epic Games, when they created Fortnite, for years and years, hired psychologists – they really dug into the human brain and they really made the effort to make it as addictive as possible,’ said Chartrand.

‘They knowingly put on the market a very, very addictive game which was also geared toward youth.’

Fortnite actually has a T for Teen rating in Canada (12 in the UK) meaning it’s only meant for ages 13 and up, so one of the minors shouldn’t even have been playing it, but it’s unclear if Chartrand knows that.

It’s also unclear what evidence there is for hiring psychologists to ensure addiction, although it’s certainly not unheard of for larger developers to use them.

The most common purpose is in helping to create microtransaction plans, although they can also be used in level design and game progression.

Although video game addiction is now listed as a mental health problem by the World Heath Organisation (WHO) research into the issue is still extremely limited and some have suggested the evidence collected so far is too weak to lead to any firm conclusions.

It also happens that Fortnite’s terms of service include a class action waiver provision, although the lawyers suggest this would not stand up against Quebec’s Consumer Protection Act.
